speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me a little bit about your pregnancy and childbirth? Were there any complications or issues during labor or delivery?

speaker: Patient
text: To be honest, I wasn't even aware I was pregnant until I was born, and my mom didn't receive any prenatal care, so I don't know much about my pregnancy.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your birth experience? Did you experience any difficulties breathing, pain, or distress immediately after birth?

speaker: Patient
text: I remember feeling a bit...dizzy after I was born. My mom said I was having trouble breathing, and the nurses were checking my heart rate a lot.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your dizziness after birth? Did it last for a short period of time or was it a persistent feeling?

speaker: Patient
text: It was more like a feeling of being unsteady, like I was floating. It went away after a few minutes, but I remember my mom being worried about me and holding me really close.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your mom's reaction when you were born? Did she seem concerned or worried about your condition, and did she report any other symptoms besides your dizziness and breathing difficulties?

speaker: Patient
text: I think my mom was really scared, to be honest. She was holding me really tightly and kept saying that I wasn't breathing right, but I don't really know what she means by that. She just seemed really worried about me, and I think she was relieved when the nurses took me away from her to check on me.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your mom's medical history? Did she have any previous health issues or complications during her pregnancies that might be relevant to your birth? Also, have you noticed any other symptoms besides the dizziness and breathing difficulties immediately after birth?

speaker: Patient
text: I'm not really sure about my mom's medical history, she didn't mention anything about previous health issues or complications during her pregnancies. And besides the dizziness and breathing difficulties, I don't think I've noticed anything else, but I do have a weird heart sound when I'm quiet, it's like a little humming noise.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about this heart sound you're referring to? Is it a constant humming noise, or does it change pitch or volume at all?

speaker: Patient
text: It's really hard to describe, but it's like a soft humming noise, almost like a gentle vibration, it's pretty quiet, but it's always there when I'm not making a lot of noise, like when I'm sleeping or quiet. Sometimes it's a bit louder when I'm crying or trying to breathe.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about this humming noise you're describing? Is it a constant presence, or does it seem to come and go at all?

speaker: Patient
text: It's always there, but sometimes it's a bit louder, like when I'm really upset or trying to breathe. It's hard to explain, but it's just this gentle humming noise that I can hear even when I'm not making any noise myself.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the humming noise? Is it a vibration that you feel in your chest or is it more of a sound you hear? And can you show me your chest and listen to your heartbeat with a stethoscope, I'd like to hear the heart sound you're describing for myself?

speaker: Patient
text: The humming noise is more of a sound I hear, it's not really a vibration, I guess. It's just a soft, gentle noise that's always there when I'm quiet.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your chest, is it larger or smaller than average? And can you show me your arms and legs, are they proportionate to the rest of your body?

speaker: Patient
text: My chest feels a bit...fuller than usual, I think. And my arms and legs seem a bit shorter than my mom said they should be.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your mom's height and build? Did she describe your arms and legs as being proportionate to the rest of your body when you were born, or did she seem concerned about their length?

speaker: Patient
text: I think my mom is about 5'2" and she's a bit petite, but I don't know if that's relevant to anything. She seemed really worried about my arms and legs when I was born, and she kept saying they were shorter than usual, but I don't know if that's just because she was worried or if it's actually true.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your mom's concerns about your arms and legs? Did she mention anything about how they seemed to be affected by your breathing difficulties, or was it more of a general concern about their length? Also, can you show me your arms and legs again, and I'd like to take a closer look at the length and proportions?

speaker: Patient
text: My mom just seemed really worried that they were shorter than usual, and she kept saying it was affecting my breathing. She was checking my heart rate a lot and seemed really concerned that something was wrong with my limbs. She was holding me really close and whispering to me, like she was trying to comfort me or something.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your breathing difficulties after birth? Did they seem to be getting worse or better over time, or were they constant?

speaker: Patient
text: I think they were getting a bit worse at first, but then they seemed to calm down after a few days. I don't really remember what it's like to breathe normally, but I know I was making a lot of effort to breathe when I was first born.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your breathing difficulties after birth? Did they seem to be getting worse or better over time, or were they constant? Also, can you describe your breathing pattern to me? Is it shallow, rapid, or do you seem to be having trouble taking full breaths?

speaker: Patient
text: I think they were getting a bit worse at first, but then they seemed to calm down after a few days. I don't really remember what it's like to breathe normally, but I know I was making a lot of effort to breathe when I was first born. It was like I was trying really hard to get air into my lungs, but it just wasn't coming in easily.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your breathing difficulties? Did you ever experience any episodes of cyanosis, where your skin turned blue or pale due to lack of oxygen? And can you try to describe to me how you feel when you're trying to breathe? Is it like you're struggling to get air into your lungs, or is it more of a feeling of tightness or constriction in your chest?

speaker: Patient
text: I think I was trying really hard to get air into my lungs when I was first born, and it just wasn't coming in easily. It was like my chest felt really tight, and I was making a lot of effort to breathe, but it was hard to get the air in. I remember feeling like I was going to pass out sometimes, but I don't know if that's exactly what it felt like.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the sensation of your chest feeling tight when you're trying to breathe? Is it a constant feeling, or does it come and go? And can you describe the sensation to me as if you're trying to breathe normally, without any effort? Also, I'd like to request a medical image of your chest X-ray to see if there's anything visible that might be contributing to your symptoms. Please take a deep breath in and out for me, and let's listen to your heart sound again with the stethoscope.

speaker: Patient
text: It's like my chest is a bit... restricted, like there's something in there that's making it hard for me to expand properly. When I try to breathe normally, it feels like I'm pushing against something, but I'm not really sure what it is.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about this feeling of restriction in your chest? Is it a constant feeling, or does it come and go? And can you try to describe to me what it's like when you're trying to breathe normally, without any effort? Also, I'd like to request a medical image of your ECG to see if there's any abnormality in your heart rhythm that might be contributing to your symptoms.

speaker: Patient
text: It's hard to describe, but when I try to breathe normally, it feels like I'm pushing against something, like there's a little wall in my chest that I have to push against to get air in. Sometimes it feels like it's moving around, like it's shifting or something.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about this feeling of pushing against a wall in your chest when you breathe? Is it a constant feeling, or does it change with different types of breathing, such as deep breaths or shallow breaths? Also, I'd like to request a medical image of your chest X-ray to see if there's anything visible that might be contributing to your symptoms.

speaker: Patient
text: It's like it's always there, but sometimes it feels a bit more intense when I'm trying to breathe really deeply. And when I'm not making a lot of noise, like when I'm sleeping or quiet, it's not as noticeable.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your sleep patterns? Do you have any trouble sleeping or do you often wake up feeling restless or uncomfortable? Also, I'd like to request a medical image of your ECG to see if there's any abnormality in your heart rhythm that might be contributing to your symptoms.

speaker: Patient
text: I don't really remember much about my sleep patterns, to be honest. I do sleep a lot, though. My mom said I was sleeping a lot when I was first born, and she was worried about me because I wasn't waking up as easily as other babies. But I'm sure it's nothing to worry about.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your mom's reaction when you were first born? Did she seem concerned about your sleep patterns, or was it more about your breathing difficulties? And did she mention anything about your heart sound, the humming noise you've been describing?

speaker: Patient
text: My mom was really scared when I was first born, she was holding me really tightly and kept saying that I wasn't breathing right, but I don't really know what she means by that. She just seemed really worried about me, and I think she was relieved when the nurses took me away from her to check on me. She didn't seem to be too concerned about my sleep patterns, though, she just said I was sleeping a lot and that was what was worrying her.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've taken note of all the information you've provided. I'm going to request a medical image of your chest X-ray to see if there's anything visible that might be contributing to your symptoms. REQUEST TEST: Chest_X-Ray Also, I'd like to request a medical image of your ECG to see if there's any abnormality in your heart rhythm that might be contributing to your symptoms. REQUEST TEST: ECG I'll review the images and your symptoms to make a diagnosis.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: - Chest_X-Ray: NORMAL READINGS - ECG: Normal readings, no significant abnormalities detected.
